author: DanielHC

title: Chevy Volt EV charge plug holder

description.text: The charging cord that comes with the Chevy Volt gets mounted near an outlet, but I wanted the charge plug end near my car. MakerBot to the rescue! Designed in SketchUp, this bracket mounts to the wall near the car and provides a convenient place to hang the plug when I'm out driving on electrons.

Step 1: Print it out
Step 2: If you want to use drywall screws to hang it up, use a countersink bit to countersink the mounting holes (I haven't figured out how to make those in SketchUp yet)
Step 3: Mount it to the wall near your car! I printed mine multicolor by switching filament to match my car (White Diamond Tricoat / Black Leather / Spice Red accents). Enjoy.

comments.text: I printed this off for my 2017 Volt, and it looks like they changed the charger. It would work if you're in a pinch, but I wouldn't recommend it.

print_settings.Notes:: I did have to fight warping, so use your own experience to prevent warping of the components during printing.

description.text:
he Mini Maze is based on the 3D-Maze V2. It is a smaller version with simpler actuators.
The path has been extended a bit.

The object is to move the "actuators" from one corner to the other.
You have to figure out that a possible movement in one dimension can be blocked in the next one.

The actuators are made from a round piece of wood 4 mm in diameter. You can find this in DIY stores. When you manage to print 4 mm rods let me know how.

Printer:

Da Vinci Mini w

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I did have to fight warping, so use your own experience to prevent warping of the components during printing.

The actuators are made from a round piece of wood 4 mm in diameter. You can find this in DIY stores. Cut 1 piece of 112 mm length and 4 pieces of 56 mm length. Assemble it in the „center“ object inside the box before you glue the top on.

title: Click Box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
01.02.2018: v2.0
Complete redesign and a new name...
Removed old files, added new stl (100x100x50mm) and of course the OpenSCAD File.

Customizer in thingiverse is not working (about 2 months now)
(you will see this error:
/usr/local/bin/openscad/openscad: error while loading shared libraries: libCGAL.so.10: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory)
So you have to use the OpenSCAD file if you want to resize the box.
I hope Thingiverse will patch this error soon (see the comments in this forum).

Pictures will follow.
Explanations will be updated as soon as possible (no promise).

04.12.2017: v2.0 coming soon.
I reduced the number of elements and redesigned the way they are connected.
So only 1 type of shelf, 1 vertical connector and 1 type of key to connect them all.

Much easier to print (I still prefer stl that don't need supports) and more stable.
Right now starting to print the shelves in black PETG. The drawers will bring the colors.

Until saturday/sunday I will update this thread with new photos and of course the new OpenSCAD-File and Customizer.

A plug'n play box. Build your using a few elements like corners, edges, plugs etc.
Easily extend or redesign it whenever you want. Use it for drawers or as a shelf or a mix of both.

Use the Customizer App for generating the necessary stl files (default is "Set" to generate one set of elements for one layer).
Or customize yourself with the attached OpenSCAD-File if you prefer it this way (I do).

The drawers are printed in one piece so that the walls can be very thin - plugging them would result in "ugly" big walls.

I use a borosilicate glass, so the bottom of the prints is very smooth. The horizontal plugs are printed upside-down. So in the end the drawers will slide without significant friction on the ledges of the horizontal plugs.

All parts can be printed without supports.

This is work in progress. Right now I'm printing new drawers with rounded front corners. I will update files and photos as soon as possible.

28.12.2016: Back from holiday

  • regenerated all stl-files (names according to scad-file)
  • added a new element (addon for vertical plug when used in combined shelves)

29.11.2016: Fixes (calculation of sockets, top lid)

27.11.2016: Udated OpenSCAD-File

  • Usable in Customizer app
  • now with correct length and width of plugs based on values for drawer length/width

RepRap

Wanhao Duplicator I3

Print speed 60 mm/s

Used Tools: OpenSCAD, Simplify3d, OctoPrint on RPI3, Wanhao Duplicator I3 in Lack enclosure

Customizable Plug'n Play Box with OpenSCAD

The most important parameters can easily be changed in the attached OpenSCAD-file.
Length, width, thickness of the drawers
Thickness of the plugs and sockets
With "adjustment" you can influence the stickyness of the elements - you should test with 2 elements for your chosen filament

description.text:
This is a bracket for mounting an exhaust blower fan within your computer case using two expansion bays. The fan can be mounted with the opening facing either side of the bracket.

The fan is a 96*33mm blower fan - specifically a Delta BFB1012H that I salvaged from an old Dell server. Using a speed controller or wiring it to run at 5 volts is recommended because these fans are loud.

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro (2016)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

You shouldn't need to print supports so long as your filament can handle bridging between short gaps.

The bracket is 1mm thin in many places - adjust your extrusion width for best results. For example, you should use a extrusion width of 0.5mm if you're using a 0.4mm nozzle (many slicers will default to 120% of the nozzle width, or 0.48mm for a 0.4mm nozzle).
The fan attaches to the bracket via two PC fan screws.
Designed in FreeCAD 0.16

remixed_from.author: Vexelius
remixed_from.title: FlashForge Creator Pro 2016 - Filament tube holder

description.text:
Here's another entry in my long tradition of improving existing designs: this is a remix of Jangles1981's hood insert sleeve for the FFCP. A sleeve like this reduces the gap in the hood to a minimum, so the heat escapes less easily during ABS prints. You don't need this for PLA prints (you should remove the hood entirely for those) unless you would be printing in an insanely cold room.

This remix has a 3D-print-software-friendly model (Slic3r wouldn't even render the original), more accurate dimensions, smoothed corners, and a design that can be easily printed without supports. It comes in a plain version, and one with a FlashForge logo (taken from a design by Vexelius).

To install it, first mount the hood as usual, then push the two ‘flaps’ of the hood inside to easily insert the sleeve, with the widest part pointing outward.

This goes well with tim_sweden's door handle draft stopper on the 2016 FFCP, to provide a draft-free enclosure. I noticed how well the enclosure was sealed when I opened the door in the middle of an ABS print, and immediately heard it crack from the thermal shock. Avoid opening the door unless you have no other choice!

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printing this in a flexible filament wil make installation easier, and reduce or eliminate rattling sounds. If you print it in an elastic filament, it may be better to scale up the X and Y dimensions by a fraction of a percent (about 0.33% would be good), and scale down the Z dimension by about 5%, so it really clamps itself to the hood.
If you print it in a rigid filament, it may be a good idea to stick some rubber to the bottom edge (e.g. a strip of cut-up bicycle tyre) to avoid rattling sounds.

comments.text: Thanks for all your work on the FFCP mods, seriously! The original of this totally wasted my time, I was new to printing and made the mistake of not turning on supports in slic3r for it. I think this is a better iteration for sure.

I was learning OpenSCAD and wanted to make an enclosure for an electronics project. Rather than create a box each time I thought it would make more sense to have a "library" file which could create the box I needed and be re-usable.

This box could also be printed as-is to hold nearly anything.

It will make a square-edged box, one with radiused corners, or a stylized version with two rounded and two squared corners opposing. It will optionally create vent holes; either round holes or square.

A note about the $fn=200; parameter. This will greatly smooth all radiused surfaces. It will also kill your processor. My poor i7-4800MQ takes about 30 minutes to render the circular holed option when this is enabled. I highly suggest you leave it commented until you are ready to export your final .STL.

Final thought: This renders properly but does not seem to like to preview. I've seen this a lot. If anyone knows why that is; I'm all ears.

Based on an Instructables article: "Creating a custom-sized box for 3D printing with OpenSCAD" by hansamannthis. I thought this needed more customization before truly being parametric:

http://www.instructables.com/id/Creating-a-custom-sized-box-for-3D-printing-with-O/

v2: Added customizable vent holes borrowed from Thorrak's "BrewPi + ESP8266 Enclosure":

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1826360

v3: Added ability to use square vent holes. Increased configurability of hole spacing.

v3.1: Addressed scaling issue between circles and squares. Now both behave as expected.

v4: Added Customizer capabilities. The Customizer doesn't render a pretty picture but the box created is correct.

v4b: Addressed rendering bugs (no impact to shape), addressed instance where vents would slightly impinge upon the radiused corners.

comments.text: Because of some "eccentricities" with how OpenSCAD deals with variable assignment, the circular and square holes behave differently.  This is because the size for the circular ones are actually the radius, IOW the size will be twice that of what you enter.  Following that logic, the spacing needs to be => that of the hole size when using a circle.  If you are using a hole size of 3, your spacing (hSpace) should be at least 3.

For my printouts, i had to do much work after printing to get good fitting parts, becaus my printer is not very exact.
So i put here a second OpenSCAD file, which produces modules with higher tolerances.

In case of future updates, both files will allways be uptated in the original thingfiles.
You will find those Updates here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1899461
Remark: The downloadable stl-files of EBS, are always produced with the low-tolerance-scad-file.
So, if you want high-tolerance-modules, you must use the scad-file. Give it a try. It's not complicated, but very intuitive.And of course, OpenSCAD is free.

Paper snowflake making during the holidays has become a tradition for me for over the past 10 years. I had my first inspiration from the following 'instructables' on how to make the most incredible snowflakes ever. These inspired me to create personal snowflake for friends and family that included their names and things of interest of those for whom I created the snowflakes gifts.

http://www.instructables.com/id/Paper-Snowflakes/
http://www.instructables.com/id/Making-Six-Sided-Paper-Snowflakes-LIKE-A-BOSS/
http://www.instructables.com/id/How-to-Make-6-Pointed-Paper-Snowflakes/

This passion has led me to a few designs that I re-create every year for the beauty and significance of the subject and the Christmas season. This is an original design that I created many years back, and this year my son suggested that I 'convert it and print it out in 3D'.

Still being a 'newbie' to 3D printing and Freecad, I wasn't sure I would be able to do it but having some experience in importing drawings (getting lucky the first time) I was able to finally 'remember' how I did it the first time.

On my first attempt of designing and printing everything came out fine. Except that I put it together wrong and the first time I tried to hang it up - it fell and broke into 4 pieces. Not wanting to throw out the pieces I made and 'repair' ring and glued it onto the broken pieces - so now I have Christmas Tree Ornaments! I have since created this 'repaired' design into a separate file to print these ornaments by themselves.
I also added the ring to the full snowflake to add extra strength to the print.

So, having realized that I put it together wrong (stars pointing in - not out), I re-designed it to look more like the original paper snowflake design. This took a bit of manipulating in FreeCad to join all the pieces. I'm finally getting more comfortable with FreeCad and can do these types of things a lot faster now.

Printer:

Geeetech i3 pro c

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

5 to 15 %

Next step: Things I've learned

Still being new to 3D printing I am still looking for the best settings for printing. Sometimes (Ok - most of the time) I have it set wrong but I'm learning to get the best infill, smoothest top and bottom, etc. I still don't have it quite correct. If anyone has any suggestions that have worked for you - please let me know.

Printing with a 5% infill has left the surface a bit rough. 15% worked a lot better - but slower print. I like the view of the infill when the sun is shinning through the print. You could even stop the print after the infill starts printing if you want a 'different' surface look.

Took a picture of my design for the paper window snowflake (folded for cutting picture) imported to Inkscape (free), scaled and converted (saved) to .svg. Imported to Freecad (free) then traced drawing to convert to 3D shape cleaning up lines as needed.
Then manipulated in the parts workbench, Mirror - flip/rotate - move until it lined up like I wanted it.

I included a picture of the paper snowflake hanging on a glass door.

The paper snowflakes are fun to do and usually leaves people in awe as they have only ever done the simple shape cuttings since grade school. Maybe give it a try as you are waiting for your 3D prints to finish.

title: Segway Sommelier, Remote Control Wine Servant

description.text:
Segway Sommelier, a Remote Control Wine Servant , to be mounted on a Ninebot Mini Pro by Segway. The Ninebot can be driven around remotely using a Bluetooth phone app.

https://youtu.be/Tkf61a0lnHo

Print (1) base section and (3) of the caddy top pieces. Remove the pad assembly from the steering arm of the 9bot by popping off a plastic plate, removing 3 screws with a hex wrench, and lifting the knee pad assembly straight up. The base assembly slips loosely over the triangular steering column. I'd recommend using a couple of shims to keep it from rattling.

it's up to you to avoid disassembly issues, broken wineglasses, frightened housepets, jealous covetous over-imbibing guests, etc. :-) I was able to easily reattach the knee pad assembly when I wanted to ride the Segway again, but there is at least one gotcha. After you lift the kneepad assembly out of the steering arm when disassembling, don't get curious and mess with the inner triangular sleeve. If you do, a ball/bearing and spring can pop out, and be difficult to put back. If you lose them, the Segway itself will still work fine but the telescoping portage arm will be a bit loose. No problem though if you leave them be in the first place.

I actually just bought an extra steering arm to make it easier to switch back and forth between riding, and robotics/performance-art configurations.

title: ENCLOSED CRAFTBOT- FULL ENCLOSURE
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hello to everyone,
i have the printer in my bedroom and due to smell made of fused filament it's very unealthy to stay there while i'm printing.
The worst thing is also that i can't open any windows because, if printing abs, the airflow 'hit' the bed causing the detachment of the print object.
So i decided to full enclose this printer, the craftbot plus (you can use the same design also for craftbot and craftbot 2), trying to limit the cost of the materials and trying to limit the visual impact.
I don't know if anyone else has already done something similar but anyway i put here my design.
The project is very simple
What you need:

  • plexiglass( the cheapest you can find in a brico center/leroy merlin etc.. is just fine) : open the picture hero on thingiverse to see cutting measures (in mm ). ps: measure as you can see in pictures are very precise because of the cad, but you can cut with +-1 mm tolerance without any problem( in case just adjust the measure with an iron/wood file)
    *glue for plexiglass ( just a little suggestion: if you put plexy scraps in the acetone for 24/48 hours you'll get a pasty compond that is perfect to join and jlue plexiglass part.) under the summary you can find a little video about it

    *some m3 screws and nuts

  • printed piece

Printer:

craftbot plus

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

very high for hinges and hinges support

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Krg43SQs4Uo" ></iframe>
plexiglass scraps + acetone = strong glue
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/0AmUWBfao5w" ></iframe>

title: Top display holder brackets for original Prusa i3 MK2

description.text:
The original Prusa i3 MK2 is a really nice printer. But I don't like the display/controller sticking out so far at the bottom front of the machine. In order to reduce the footprint I thought it would be a good idea to move the unit to the top next to the spool holder since the "bounding box" of the machine would not be changed by the controller (if you understand what I mean ...).

So I used the original Prusa i3 MK2 STL files and remixed a new bracket from the spool holder and the display holder (right one). Since editing STL files with 123Design seems to be a bit strange I sliced both components in the middle (vertical) and created an SVG file with the 2D shape and then extruded it to the right thickness.

First try = fit. Really nice :-)

Print instructions: print them twice (in orange filament to blend in perfectly). I used PLA and the fit and strength is perfectly.

Printer:

Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

0.2mm

20%

No special provisions needed.

My first try at a lasercut castle

This is a DLP projector-based resin printer that can make very fine 3D prints in record time. This is a work in progress. Today I plan to begin actual experiments with the resin. I believe the basic design I am producing here is very suitable, however, the details of the design need changes in almost every part to be ideal. Most importantly, the vat should probably be much shorter, but the whole thing could be made significantly smaller. I am currently using resin from
Bucktown Polymers: http://bucktownpolymers.com/ (You might notice their price for resin is cheaper than some current PLA prices, by volume) A2Sheds has provided a page with a few helpful resources, as well as the beginnings of his own DLP project: http://code.google.com/p/lemoncurry/wiki/main This is very much a work in progress. Expect more photos and videos to come. Here's a link to my flickr site documenting this project: http://www.flickr.com/photos/[email protected]/sets/72157629564335469/ Video of resin cure here:
http://youtu.be/UVDN2xq575A Next steps: Experiment with resin. Create working software stack. Known Issues: Vat is too tall/big, glass may be too weak/thin. Vat probbaly needs a nonstick coating, like silicone or PTFE. Z Axis range is 5", vat is 5", so Z stage cannot quite clear the vat. A2Sheds recommends a heated vat to 50c so the resin flows better...

1) Get yourself a DLP projector with a Xenon bulb -- not the ones with LEDs. Open it up, and use a pair of pliers to break all the glass edges off of the color wheel. I'll take some photos later, but it's pretty obvious what is the color wheel; it's just like it sounds, a wheel with some various colored glass bits on it that the light goes through to make the colors. If you break off the colored glass and leave the wheel in the projector, you don't have to worry about whether the projector will sense the wheel missing and refuse to run; it still thinks the wheel is there. 2) While you're all up int he projector, loosen the final optics, the focusing part, and move it further away from the innards of the projector to get a closer, narrower focus. You want it to oply be a couple-few inches across. Remember, when you do print, it's the resolution of your projector over the area of your focus that determines how fine your print can ultimately be, so smaller area and greater resolution is ideal. 3) Construct the frame - you should see how it works from the photos. There's two MDF clamps in the bottom to hold the projector in the proper position.

  • Using a rubber mallet to pound the smooth rod into the Z axis ends is a good plan.

  • I've included a copy of nophead's Z coupler here, slightly modified. Instead of using vinyl tubing, I attach the coupler to the threaded rod, then shoot the open end full of hot glue, and then quickly attach the motor end before it cools. I find this works spectacularly well.
    • 4) Adjust the position of the projector so it focuses on the bottom of the vat, by dropping a bit of paper on the bottom of the vat to see how you're doing. 5) Get to experimenting... if you've come this far you're about as far along as I am. For the record, the "Pronterface" host suite supports (to some tiny extent) prjecting an SVG for printing, and Skeinforge can export them, but I'm working on something a little more tuned to the task as well. COSTS SO FAR: 1 used but working DLP projector from eBay: $75
    1 2'x4' MDF sheet: $10
    (some) 8mm threaded rod: A few bucks
    1 8mm smooth rod: A few bucks
    Buncha 8mm Nuts and Washers: A few bucks
    1 5"x5"x5" fishtank: $25 (not a good choice)
    1 bit of glass for the platform: $5ish
    1 Stepper motor: $7 I'm currently using a RAMPS board to drive the stepper because I had some on hand, but any cheap little single motor driver should do.

title: Billow V1 Tank Glass
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Replacement glass tube for the EHPRO Billow V1 RTA.

Glass replacement tanks are hard to find, so after some trial and error, I was able to make a good replacement. I have yet to test it, but seems like it should seal well and work as intended. be sure to read the print instructions.

If you use this to get your Billow up and running again, please consider tipping me, It takes time and effort to continue to post designs for the community here. Thanks!

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm layers

Infill:

none (vase print)

Notes:

Print this part at .2mm layer height maximum, thinner if you are able. Bump your temperature up a little to promote good layer adhesion. Mine was printed in old-school Makerbot natural PLA @ 233 degrees (I have a few spools on hand).

Print as a vase (4 shells layer width @.4mm) no floor, no roof. use a raft to prevent the bottom lip of the tank from distorting/fitting too tight, as this will keep it from sealing properly. there should be little to no post-print cleanup. Natural PLA (or any translucent color) is best to monitor your juice level.

The cylinder itself was generated and smoothed in two passes in wings3D, This part was then adjusted and scaled in Makerware and then saved as an STL after multiple test prints when the fit was perfect on the silicone gaskets.

Modelling the part as a tube produced poor results, as there was always a gap between the walls, no matter the infill settings. in some cases the inside wall was completely separate from the outer wall. Treating it as a vase print on a cylinder of the correct outer diameter did the trick, as it let me control the thickness of the tank wall, gave the best layer adhesion, and was easily adjusted to get the fit on the o-rings perfect. This is why the part posted is a solid cylinder. Printing it in the standard fashion won't work. There are plenty of tutorials out there on doing vase prints. if you use a Makerbot printer, I can share my print profile settings upon request.

I plan to drill some small holes to allow light to pass through, though the holes need to be very small so are not modelled. I'll also drill some holes for green LEDs in the dish, though this is still a work in progress. I'll add more pics when I have a chance to clean it up a bit and get lights installed.

Printed in silver Hatchbox PLA. The one I printed took around 14hrs for each half, and is about 6" in diameter, which if I recall correctly was scaled about 60% from the models.

comments.text: I have not tried to drill holes in PLA before. Was this difficult to get all those holes drilled? Was wondering whether it would be easier to take the model and create the tiny holes before printing?  What size drill bit did you use?  Great idea for a Star Wars tree topper!!!
comments.author: sharonkay

comments.text: I haven't tried printing the holes because I didn't have faith my printer would be able to make holes small enough cleanly as I was having time dialing it in well enough for that at the time. You are welcome to remix with holes added! Drilling the holes was tedious but did not take as long as I expected. Initially I tried drilling with a .5mm bit but it was too delicate and broke after about 4-5 holes. Instead I went with the smallest 'standard' bit I could find which was 3/32" if I recall correctly. Do not use a Dremel or similar for this as they are simply too many RPMs and will heat PLA enough to melt and make the resulting holes larger than intended. I used a regular power drill with the small bit and much patience. If you find melted PLA building up on the bit, keep a piece of scrap wood handy and drilling into that will usually clean off the melted plastic. I'd say it took me an hour or so to do the whole thing, and another hour or two cleaning up the holes with an xacto. Unfortunately I've not been able to come up with a better way, but would be interesting to see if pre-modeled holes come out. I simply assumed it would not and didn't try.
comments.author: sharonkay

title: Lathe CNC easy mount Jet BD7 Nema 17

description.text:
** New Update for Z motor mount => http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1925138

*Update. Attached is the drawing nema17 motor mount. Apply basic dimensions.

It's my easy lathe project.
CNC mount Nema 17 motors on Jet BD7 (it's 300mm Mini Lathe).
For CNC i use GRBL CNC.

You will need:

  1. Bolt M6x20-25.
  2. Washer 8x25-30x6mm
  3. And it's required to modify the handle longitudinal feed.
    The handle must be in a horizontal position when switched off.

There is one remark. Progress of longitudinal feed is reduced by 16mm.
it is not critical for me.

When you install the motor in the mount, first disassemble the motor.

For Z-axis, you can also print a bracket for mounting the motor, but I do not have time for modeling this.

The motor and gears are installed tightly in their plases. The gaps are not allowed.
It is very important to have a good calibrated printer.

Ask questions if something is not clear.
.

CoreXY

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

30-80

Notes:

I printed it in ABS but i think PLA is good to.

Nozzle 0.4, extrusion 0.5, 1 perimeter.
Layer 0.1

I think if you use a nozzle 0.2 you get better. But the printing time will increase greatly.
Post printing not needed. Just calibrate your printer.

description.text:
... still trying to get comfortable with openSCAD, so i decided to create these parametric filament-splitter for dual-material-prints with a single nozzle.

This is a work-in-process and somtimes i am still struggling with jams (especially when the filament enters the hotend (e3dv5-china-clone)).

Nevertheless - good luck :)

The following script is for Simplify3D (@ToolChange Script) to change the filament and purge the nozzle.
You have to set the values for retract and feed to your needs.

####################################################
T[old_tool]
G1 X-70 Y0 F6000 ; go to purge position
G92 E0
G1 E-20.000 F12000 ; retract
G1 E-30.000 F1200 ; retract
G1 E-130.000 F12000 ; retract

T[new_tool]
G92 E0
G1 E110.000 F900 ; feed 11cm
G1 E120.000 F420 ; feed 1cm
G1 E140.000 F240 ; feed 2cm
G92 E0
####################################################

Ne ho fatto due versioni, uno più alto dell'altro di 10cm circa, così da poter posizionare gli altoparlanti a diversa distanza, differienzando fronte da surround.
Gli altroparlanti per cui li ho realizzati hanno dimensione 15,5x17,5x25 per circa 3kg di peso.
I piedi hanno un diametro di 20mm e le seguenti lunghezze:

title: Marble Pump
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Just a marble pump, do nothing style. Marble pumps have been around for years and, most often, are made of wood. I've made quite a few out of wood, but each time it required "whittling" to make it work. With a 3D printer, no whittling is required (well, except for a few stray strands in the arches). Video of just a marble pump here http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p9qddnKNb-E. Uses 14mm size marbles. The photo and video show the marble pump motorized, but the motor is not required as the crankshaft can easily be spun by hand (maybe someone will add a handle?). Printed in PLA using Makerware 2.3.3.42 ("Standard" settings) and a Replicator 2. This assembly is a test for a larger project. UPDATES: 1) "Someone" (me) added a handle and a minimized base. Vrack requested a handle for the non-motorized version of Marble Pump. The files "Handle.stl" and "Base No Motor.stl" have been added as requested. Haven't tested them yet.

Study "Assembly.skp", a Sketchup 8 file. If you want to motorize yours, you'll need: 1) "6VDC 45 RPM Pinky Finger Sized Gear Motor 1" Long x 15/32" x 3/8"" from either amazon.com or directly from http://sciplus.com/p/MICROMOTOR_47952. Other sources are available, I've not tested them though. 2) Coaxial Power Jack - Radio Shack part number 274-1583. 3) 3 Vdc Power Supply - Radio Shack part number 273-315. 4) 22 gauge wire. "Slide.stl", "Journal Crankshaft.stl", and "Crankshaft.stl" can be a little little tricky to assemble inside "Housing.stl".

author: Dkesler

print_settings.Notes:: I printed at 0.1mm because I screwed up and forgot to switch to 0.2mm. No reason for this thing to have such a fine Z resolution. I used 100% infill to make sure it was strong but primarily to give it more mass (even if a tiny amount more) to contribute to good, long spin times. With 6 bearings in the perimeter and a solid frame, this thing spins longer than anything else I've printed.

description.text:
I came up with my Cinco hand spinner fidget when I had six bearings left over after making one of the many triple fidget spinners. But, since bigger is always better, I realized the next step was to go to six outer bearings, and with six outer bearings, what better idea than an homage to a revolver cylinder?

This doesn't serve any purpose other than being the next step bigger, which is in and of itself an homage to the ridiculous escalation that always happens in any consumer product, whether it's megapixels in cameras or gigahertz in processors or whatever... we always need more even after we sail right past all that we really needed.

It's pretty darn big, and I still prefer the original triple spinner, but hey, it's something different.

I've included a spinner button which has a shoulder to stand the main body off of the bearing. I noticed that the buttons I had originally printed would occasionally rub on the bearing and slow it down, so I added the stepped shoulder to prevent that, and made the overall diameter slightly larger. NOTE: my button design really isn't all that good - it's hard to print, and the size of the shaft is a little too small to make it a press fit into the bearing. Because of this, I recommend skipping my end caps altogether and checking out some of the other awesome designs available here. Thanks to malakid who posted a print and linked to [these cool bullseye caps)[https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2335142] which fit nicely with the theme of the "six shooter" spinner itself.

With 6 bearings in the perimeter and a solid frame, this thing spins longer than anything else I've printed.

author: Janeicy

description.text:
The problem with power strips is the keyhole slot on the back you're supposed to use to mount it with. They are a pain to get lined up, a screw set and the power strip actually hooked on. Then, if you look at it wrong the power strip comes loose and requires two hands to plug/unplug a cord.

These simple brackets let you screw the power strip securely to a wall, work bench or inside a cabinet. They should fit most type of power strips as you can see from the photos.

I suggest printing them from ABS or something similar for strength but PLA might work okay too.

title: Yet Another Diamond Hot End Mount for Ultimaker

description.text:
I was not satisfied with existing ultimaker hot end mounts because I wanted a mount where the nozzle was easily removable and that only used two LM6UU bearings just like the normal ultimaker hot end mount. I also wanted space to mount two cooling fans on the sides because I've had a lot of success with that setup in the past.

Here is what I've come up with! Let me know if you want any additional help with assembling your diamond hot end! It really is a great addition to an already great printer.

I also included a zip containing solidworks source files, for easy editing!

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker Original

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 mm

Infill:

12.5 %

Notes:

I used a brim to prevent unsticking. The open square part where the fan mounts is down.

I had to sand the holes where the bearings mount to get them to fit. Also, I ended up drilling a few extra holes afterwards to mount the circuit board I use for organizing wires.

Also, the square hot end mounting clamps stick out too much in some places so I sort of chopped them down to size. This could easily be altered in the model but I couldn't be bothered. Maybe I'll do it eventually.

description.text:
This is a low-profile bracket for the Mellanox ConnectX-2 single port 10Gbit card. You can find used cards for dirt cheap on eBay, but they usually only come with full-sized brackets. The bracket may work on the other Mellanox cards, but I can't confirm this.

Finding low-profile brackets for this card was nearly impossible when I first decided to design this bracket. Thankfully you can find some on eBay nowadays.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

You will need to print some supports for the edges. If your slicer isn't generating the supports properly, then try rotating the part on the z-axis and try generating again.
You will need to tap the card mounting holes. It's plastic though, so you should be able to 'self tap' by driving the screw straight into the hole - no tap and die necessary.

Designed in FreeCAD 0.16

You can change the size and position of PortCutout if you want to try making a dual-port card.

title: Galaxy S7 Edge Tripod Mount and Stand

description.text:
This Is for mounting a Galax S7 Edge to a tripod mount using a 1/4-20 Tee nut inserted into the plastic. It also functions as a stand to hold the phone in a horizontal or vertical position on a flat surface. I have also included a slice out of the model for test fitting purposes so you don't have to waist an entire print. I modeled this after a model I downloaded a couple years ago for my Galaxy S4 on here. I cannot find that thing on here anymore to give credit for design. I Just measured it all out and redrew/reshaped it in 123d Design and have loaded those files here so you can modify it or whatever.

I had to reshape the model from the one in the pics to have a square shoulder on the tripod mount front side so it would stay standing horizontally with the phone in it. I left the model in the 123d file that has a rounded edge on the tripod mount side like in the pics, that model will not let the phone stand in the horizontal position because... gravity but I left it in there just because.

This is my first upload. If anyone can tell me how to add the 3d model view into the preview I would appreciate it. Also any feedback.

title: Height adjustable router attachment for rotary tool

description.text:
You can attach this thing to your Dremel to turn it into a router. Basically it provides the same functionality as a Dremel 565 kit.

adjustable-router-attachment.stl contains all the parts.
base-only.stl and mount-only.stl (uploaded as per MrJelle's request) allow you to print them separately.

Printer:

Stampacose

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.15 mm

Infill:

45%
You just need to add an M5 nut and a M5x10 screw.

I designed this with openSCAD.
It's fully parametric so you can customize it to your liking using to the provided .scad file. But first you need to download this library: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8793.
